unnormalised: ## The Great ATM Heist (of My Dignity)
normalised: ## The Great A-T-M Heist (of My Dignity)

unnormalised: So, there I was, armed with my SBI debit card and a burning desire to withdraw Rs. 2000. It was my cousin Priya’s wedding, and I was tasked with getting the flower garlands. Turns out, fancy flowers don't accept UPI. Who knew?
normalised: So, there I was, armed with my S-B-I debit card and a burning desire to withdraw rupee two thousand. It was my cousin Priya’s wedding, and I was tasked with getting the flower garlands. Turns out, fancy flowers don't accept U-P-I. Who knew?

unnormalised: The first ATM, a HDFC Bank one near my office in Bandra, was "temporarily out of service." Of course it was. Isn't that always the way? Strike one. I figured, no worries, there's another one just down the road, a Kotak Mahindra Bank machine.
normalised: The first A-T-M, a H-D-F-C Bank one near my office in Bandra, was "temporarily out of service." Of course it was. Isn't that always the way? Strike one. I figured, no worries, there's another one just down the road, a Kotak Mahindra Bank machine.

unnormalised: Walked over, swiped my card (after sanitizing, naturally – gotta be COVID-safe!), and entered my PIN. The screen whirred, the gears grinded… and then, nothing. Just a blank stare from the ATM. No money. No receipt. Just the cold, hard rejection of a machine built for a single purpose.
normalised: Walked over, swiped my card (after sanitizing, naturally – gotta be C-O-V-I-D-safe!), and entered my P-I-N. The screen whirred, the gears grinded… and then, nothing. Just a blank stare from the A-T-M. No money. No receipt. Just the cold, hard rejection of a machine built for a single purpose.

unnormalised: Panic started to set in. Had I entered the wrong PIN? Was my account frozen? Was this some elaborate, Bollywood-esque heist targeting my meager savings? I checked my phone – no suspicious activity. Called the SBI helpline, navigated through the automated maze, and finally got a human voice. After 15 minutes of explaining, she assured me the transaction hadn't gone through and my ₹2000 was safe. Okay, breathe.
normalised: Panic started to set in. Had I entered the wrong P-I-N? Was my account frozen? Was this some elaborate, Bollywood-esque heist targeting my meager savings? I checked my phone – no suspicious activity. Called the S-B-I helpline, navigated through the automated maze, and finally got a human voice. After fifteen minutes of explaining, she assured me the transaction hadn't gone through and my rupee two thousand was safe. Okay, breathe.

unnormalised: But the flowers! Priya’s face flashed before my eyes. I remembered there was a Canara Bank ATM near the local railway station. I hopped into an auto-rickshaw (fare: Rs. 60 - inflated thanks to wedding season). Finally, success! The machine dispensed the money – crisp, new notes. I even got a receipt.
normalised: But the flowers! Priya’s face flashed before my eyes. I remembered there was a Canara Bank A-T-M near the local railway station. I hopped into an auto-rickshaw (fare: rupee sixty - inflated thanks to wedding season). Finally, success! The machine dispensed the money – crisp, new notes. I even got a receipt.

unnormalised: But then, the auto driver refused to accept anything but ₹500 notes because he 'didn't have change'. Seriously?! After all that? I ended up buying him chai worth ₹10 from a nearby stall to break the note. The whole ordeal had taken over an hour.
normalised: But then, the auto driver refused to accept anything but rupee five hundred notes because he 'didn't have change'. Seriously?! After all that? I ended up buying him chai worth rupee ten from a nearby stall to break the note. The whole ordeal had taken over an hour.

unnormalised: Lessons learned: Always carry backup cash, even in the age of digital payments. Maybe get a credit card with a decent rewards program (and a higher withdrawal limit). And always, *always* factor in the unpredictable chaos of Indian banking. Now to go purchase those flower garlands!
normalised: Lessons learned: Always carry backup cash, even in the age of digital payments. Maybe get a credit card with a decent rewards program (and a higher withdrawal limit). And always, *always* factor in the unpredictable chaos of Indian banking. Now to go purchase those flower garlands!
